summary.text_en: Danish astronomer Ole RÃ¸mer, working at the Paris Observatory, made a fundamental discovery by observing the eclipses of Jupiter's moon 'Io'. He noticed that the eclipses happened 'later' than predicted when Earth was moving away from Jupiter, and 'earlier' when Earth was moving closer. He correctly deduced this was not an irregularity in the moon's orbit, but because 'light takes time' to travel the extra distance. He calculated it took light about 22 minutes to cross Earth's orbit diameter. This was the first proof in history that the speed of light is *finite*, not instantaneous.
key_points_en: Proved the speed of light is 'Finite'
Observed the correlation between 'Time Lag' and distance
Disproved the Aristotelian/Cartesian view that light is 'instantaneous'

story.text_en: RÃ¸mer's original task was practical: to use the frequent, regular eclipses of Io (every 42.5 hours) as a 'cosmic clock' to help sailors find 'longitude'. He gathered years of data to make a schedule. He found a puzzling pattern: if he made predictions based on when Earth was closest, the eclipses were ~22 minutes *late* when Earth was on the other side of the Sun (farthest away). His boss, Cassini, noticed this too but hesitated to abandon old theories. RÃ¸mer boldly announced: that 22 minutes is the time light takes to cross Earth's orbit. He predicted the exact 'delay' for the next eclipse in 1676 to the French Academy, and he was exactly right.

fun_facts.text_en: Despite RÃ¸mer's solid evidence, his famous boss, Giovanni Cassini, refused to accept the idea of 'finite light speed' until his death.

RÃ¸mer didn't actually calculate a speed in km/s (like 300,000), because no one knew the exact diameter of Earth's orbit yet. It was Christiaan Huygens who later used RÃ¸mer's data to calculate the actual number.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine sending a letter to a friend. If you move further away from your friend, the letter takes longer to arrive.
RÃ¸mer found that 'light' is like that letter. Io acts like a 'flash signal' sent on a schedule. When Earth moved further away from Jupiter, we saw that 'flash' later than expected. This proved light doesn't arrive 'instantly'; it takes time to travel the distance, like a messenger.

applications.text_en: Establishing that light speed is finite meant that looking at the distant universe is looking into the *past*. This is the basis of modern astronomy.

applications.text_en: Although RÃ¸mer was working on longitude, the fact of finite light speed is the core principle of modern GPS (which works by measuring signal delay).

impact.text_en: RÃ¸mer's discovery was a massive leap in physics epistemology. Before this, most thinkers (including Kepler and Descartes) thought light was instantaneous. Proving it had speed meant it was a 'physical entity' moving through space. This directly influenced Huygens's wave theory (`huygens_wave_theory_1690`) and later Maxwell's calculation (`maxwell_equations_1861`) of light speed.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Galileo (discovered the moons of Jupiter, providing the 'clock' RÃ¸mer needed)
Cassini (as RÃ¸mer's mentor, set up the program to observe Jupiter's moons)

influenced.contribution_en: Huygens (used RÃ¸mer's data to calculate the numerical speed of light for the first time, supporting his wave theory)
Maxwell (when his calculated EM wave speed matched RÃ¸mer/Huygens's light speed, it confirmed light was an EM wave)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: RÃ¸mer was the first to tell us that when we look at the stars, we are seeing 'history', not the 'present'.
